description:
1# LUMPIA IN SAN FRANCISCO 
Third time I've had lumpia in my life an first time from here they were absolutely perfect didn't even use sauce for eI was lucky enough to get them fresh from the kitchen too definitely need a Filipino woman in my life I never knew I would fall in love with a culture and food. UPDATE Sept 2018 I've tried Lumpia from four other places including a food truck downtown.... BEST F'n LUMPIA IN THE CITY SF!!!!!!
author: Rolin S.

description:
Good flavors
Cheap costs
Easy access
Not so clean
Great value.
Will come again. This place is almost an institution.
author: Jorydude r.

description: so delicious, INCREDIBLY CHEAP and the staff are lovely and hardworking. every dish here is fantastic but the lumpia is definitely a crowd favorite for good reason. perfectly crisp and flavored. I love. Come here if you want authenthic, way better than Jollibees. One of the hidden food gems of SF, honestly.
author: Steel Blue S.

description:
What is Irma's Pampanga?

The waft of delicious food pours out of the swinging metal door. It's a converted something or other, by the looks of the 70s ceiling (Is it asbestos? And more importantly do I give two sh!ts.) The kitchen goes all  the way back and it's as long as the dining area. The entire space is split by a 3 by 10 foot serving space, one of those glass-hot water-tray contraptions, which you will swear was heaven on earth. 

A big burly white guy who hasn't shaved in 15 minutes will quickly usher out the crackies looking for a free lumpia with his less-than-jedi mind trick yelling. He just says "no" but the rebuke on their lifestyle goes deeper than the word, because after all, Irma's catholic.

And her food is divine.

So what is Irma's Pampanga?
A small corner spot in the Mission?
A city space in central Luzon?

A tiny bit of what's left of your MSG-loving heart?
author: John C.

description: I ordered pancit, 1 stick chicken bbq, and sisig and was charged $17 at the Tikim festival. It was quite a rip off to say the least. At least it could have tasted good but it was bland and quite frankly a poor representation of Pampanga's cuisine. I truly expected more.
author: Dflipsyde S.

description:
It seems pretty old school with granny scooping out melons at a table right where you walk by to order, with the melon rinds stacking up and the flies swirling and granny cleaning off tables then returning to continue her scooping  to make the juice and no hand washing going on at all.

I liked the prices. Pork on a stick $2.50 and three lumpia $2. So for $4.50 it's a deal

It's not the friendliness or the cleanest and outside you have the iffy characters milling about
But I've lived here so long I'd like to go back to try the pancit
author: Foodlover B.

description:
If only Irma's tasted as good as it looked. I love the turo-turo (basically all the food is laid out buffet style behind a glass divider- customer would then pick and point to the food they want- turo in Tagalog means point- hence Turo-turo ) concept- I believe that this style is truest to the Filipino way of serving food. The upside of seeing your food already prepared in front of you is that one hopes that you choose as much as you want - the down side is - you see everything down to its greasy sheen and other unappetizing feature it may have.  
I ordered the party standard - bbq, lumpia and pansit-  the BBQ was meh- and the lumpia tasted old and the pansit was bland.  It's very rare when  I don't finish my Filipino food  - it was a sad time.  I really wanted Irma to work out for me since I work a few blocks away-  alas - no go-to Filipino food for me  around the way. 

Side-note: while I was ordering - the server accidentally dropped some receipts into the food (adobo) she didn't even blink nor think twice about it- grabbed it with her bare hands and set that sucker on the counter- and went right back to business as if. That. Just. Did. Not. happen.   Well alright then there goes my appetite.
author: Michelle B.

description: Health score pretty low! I asked to use the restroom and it was filthy, so Let's assume the kitchen might not be that different! Yuck!
author: Viv J.

description: Really good grandma-style Filipino food. The lechon is my fav.
author: Keith P.

description: The food here is amazing. Definetly cheap and delicious! Never had filipino food except for lumpia's but here the BBQ Pork and the Lumpias are too much to handle. DELICIOUS
author: Sarah C.

description: Just like my mom makes!  Large portions to make sure you're full. Enough for 2 meals.
author: F B.

description:
If you want awesome Filipino food this place is delicious. Irma's has everything I love. The flavor is perfect.
The portions are big and I couldn't finish, but I enjoyed every bit. I actually like it better then Phil Am.
author: Ahna B.

description: I love this place is open for breakfast at 8am. They have awesome adobo , garlic fried rice and longanesa waiting for you to start your day! Tastes like my mom's cooking !!
author: Ed C.

description:
Irma's rocks!!!!!

SUPER great deal for Lumpia, and Irma's bistek and sinigang are *always* on point. 

Do yourself a favor and hit up Irma's ASAP if you're in the neighborhood and in the mood for a little Filipino goodness. ~*
author: Pamela ..

description: Walked in and walked out! There were 4 ladies chilling at a table as if they were playing cards yet they were sitting there preparing food at the main tables! I was to going to get some take out but none of them stopped to ask if I needed help. The food looked like it was sitting out for awhile and swimming in grease. Probably best off I didn't order from here. Thinking food should be prepared in a kitchen and not at the customer tables. Gross!
author: Aj C.

description:
This is definitely authentic!!! Their igado is amazing (reminds me of summers in the province when I was a kid!).  I also love that the Lola's are wrapping lumpias and dishing gossip right on the dining area!!! 
If you like Ilocanos style cooking this is the ish!!! 

!!!
author: Gio A.

description: Ok where do I start?! Lumpias are great but how disgusting can you be as an employee. 3 ladies sitting at a table eating, as I'm ready to order one of the ladies takes her sweet time getting up as she's liking her food off her fingers. Goes to the sink and only rinses her hands with water and then tries to grab the chicken skewers with her hands!!! Oh hell no lady!!!!!
author: Alma V.

description: Microwaved food, food probably has been sitting there all day long, questionable sanitary practices. Location is bad, a lot of homeless people just roaming around the building and sitting inside the restaurant when they clearly didn't even order anything. Nope just nope lost my appetite
author: Fran N.

description:
No matter how average everything else is at this place, my coworkers love ordering Turon from Irma's. The caramelized banana wrapped in lumpia wrapper and deep fried is the only way we know to end a potluck on a high note. We usually get a full tray of golden fried bananas for a measly price of $25 and it's good for 15 people with many extras to take home. 

I would like to think I have a stomach of steel since I've actually been inside the restaurant and their cleanliness is definitely questionable. Also, since this is near the 16th BART station, you get questionable characters hanging around the area too. 

Don't say I didn't warn you.
author: Janice C.

description:
$10 will get you a good, hearty meal with Tita Irma's! She is a really cool lady! Lunch time here gets busy, but the turnaround of customers eat quick, so you will always find a seat. She has many locals that dine here and it's fun to chat with them. She is on the corner of 16th and South Van Ness, only a block away from the 16th Bart Station. She also does party tray. I recommend her Shanghai Lumpias and her BBQ. Give her 48 hours notice, and she'll get it ready for ya in a jiffy!

Until then, Cheers! ~ :p
author: Edwin R.

description: What can I say, it was the best dining experience I've ever had in SF. Felt like dining with family in the Philippines. The food was delicious and highly authentic. The service was extremely nice. They let us try a bit of each dish before deciding, and patiently explained which dishes are more for the specific philipino pallet and which are more suitable for everyone - we took a mix of both, and each and every dish tasted amazing. This is now our top choice in SF, by a wide margin.
author: Norcloud S.

description: Simply put, everything tastes just like home. Reminds of the typical " carinderia " back in the philippines.
author: Kia M.

description: This used to be my go to place whenever I have a hankering for Filipino food but will not go here again.  I wanted to buy like 30 lumpia for a potluck at my school. As I walked to the restaurant I saw a woman walk out with a white carton taking a lumpia out, dipping it in sauce and eating it as she walked by. I thought to myself "Great! They have lumpia!". I walk in and I see a small tray of lumpia. No one was at the counter so I waited. The woman I saw earlier came back and she flagged down the guy behind the counter as he made his way back. "This lumpia is cold." She hands the carton to the guy.  The guy looks in the carton and then proceeds to dump the lumpia in the carton back into the tray of lumpia that I was gonna buy. I turned around and left the restaurant.
author: Jazmin J.

description: The San Francisco I love is in full effect! Ethnic, edgy, slightly grungy. .  Though I have seen this down-home mom and pop several times over the years and heard rave reviews from several Filipinos, I had never visited.  But when you've been dancing samba in the hot sun from 8am to 3pm, you desperately need carbs, a clean bathroom, and a place to sit and relax.  My dance sisters and I with our respective families all visited Irma's for a very late lunch.  My daughter devoured her veggie lumpias. I ordered a two-item combo(much too big for a mom and small child; next time we're getting a one-item combo) of chicken adobo, chicken curry, and steamed rice. The food was good. My orange Fanta was cold and sweet.  We chatted among ourselves but also watched a telenovela featuring a shady drag queen and the Filipino version Family Feud. Definitely met all our exhausted dancer expectations.
author: Julie C.

description:
Irma's turned out the bomb breakfast this morning. 

We had the crispy Bangsilog, tasty Tocilog, delicious Longsilog, fresh hot Lechon, Lumpia Shanghai.. and a couple pieces of Ukoy fried heaven. 

There was such a variety of things that we didn't sample today too.. saving it for next time.

Quote from Boogie, "I feel like it's my Birthday!"

Extra points for being a family joint: Baby still sleeping in the corner :) I remember the playpen days.
author: Andy K.

description: Love their food. Big portions though. Couldn't finish my food  great service though. My gf is part Filipino and Hawaiian. She knows what kind of foods are great so I went with her answer.
author: Mike L.

description: I do yoga most saturdays on Mission and 16th and often head for the night to Nicasio (West Marin) to jam music with friends for the night. We do pot luck, so after yoga, i usually pick up 3 dozen lumpia (hand made to order $3/12), and 4 chicken skewers. Total comes out to less than $20, and sooo good. Always a hit with the band for apps before we play. I've had everything on the menu, and love bfast at Irma's, but just calling out... if you're heading to pot luck party, these are a couple items that are just awesome and always a hit. Don't forget a few to-gos of the sweet sauce for dipping the lumpia!!
author: Adam X.

description:
The greasiest spoon yet, in any category. No quality food here, only the sloppy presentation and ingredients typical of the average Filipino or Mexican restaurant.

On the bright side, the mung bean stew over rice is comforting.
author: Inigo M.

description:
I stop in there every now and then. The sisig and adobo is decent; parking can be a little hard to find and make sure to hide your belongings in your vehicle. This neighborhood is kinda sketchy. 
Lots of seating, always.
author: Shaun R.

description:
I have been going to Irma's for at least 3 years and the food has never disappointed.  Prices are extremely reasonable & the food is always flavorful and fresh.  The place isn't glamorous but it has a true hole-in-the-wall vibe.  It's a family-owned business so the staff are all warm and friendly.  

Some of my favorites:
1) The lumpia (some of the best I've ever tried)
2) The barbecue chicken or pork - saucy & delicious
3) Pork Sisig - the right amount of spicy & savory
author: Stuart G.

description:
Been going here on average once a week for probably 6 months now. 
Consistently delicious food. 
Service can be lol and the place isn't pretty but it's just perfect for the type of food. 
Much Better than kababayan
author: Mr M.

description: My partner and many close friends are Filipino and told me this place was a good local place.  I'm an Adobo lover and Irma and her sister do not dissapoint.  My friends say it's authentic and has most of the dishes they grew up with.
author: Kenneth N.

description:
dont ever buy at a special festival etc.
today's filipino festival in sf downtown, the rpice on the food kept increasing.
1st 26 for 2 plates, then 29, then 32 then 33 as they felt like ripping off the public. other people in line complained as well as no prices were posted.
2nd the food was old and cold as well.
author: joe b.

description:
It was one of those experiences that you know is "authentic" when you finish ALL of your chicken adobo (because it was that good), only to find a thumb sized cockroach crawling up the seat across from you.

yes, ill be coming back!
author: Nicole L.

description:
Yikes have to downgrade my rating. First the lady serving behind the counter is not the happiest of all people. I don't think she's Irma, but maybe Irma's long-suffering sister who hates her. Really bad service. 

Second, since I've been back multiple times, I find the food can be hit or miss. But mostly miss. It's turo-turo so the food sits there maybe all day, and maybe into the next day and the next, etc. The quality is questionable. After this last visit, we may not go back for a while. Most of the food we had seemed old. And esp the candy we bought.. OMG I almost threw up. It may have expired last year.. maybe. 

Too bad because I really loved Irma's the first few times, and so convenient to me being downtown. Guess I'll have to make that trip to Daly City again for better Filipino food. Or Kusina ni Tess downtown!
author: Vol T.

description:
Good for taking your hunger away... I guess.

Went to this food tent during a festival. All the egg rolls were so fried, and they were more skin than filling. I got the three item combo for $12, running a bit expensive since you can get a sandwich for half that and call it lunch. Especially since most of it was rice. Not exotic, just plain white flavorless. I wonder if maybe I got charged too much and was supposed to go for the 2 item combo with rice. Either way the server didn't say anything about it. Except "Yes, 12." There was two kinds of noodles, neither vegetarian. Both had the same meat too. For me, it was a good thing there wasn't much pork and the pieces were tiny.

Don't want their little business to do badly just because of my review, but, guess because it's all meat and it's not grass fed I feel better.
author: M R.

description: Awful. I wanted to try this to see if it's good. Don't fall for the Pampanga name. Food is bad. Very unsanitary overall.
author: Dean Q.

description:
Well yes it's a little dodgy but you can't beat the price and the taste. Great to buy and go. Things to try: Fried lumpia ... Total hit at any party, I personally like the vegetable v the pork.
They also have a party platter for $120 that will get you through feeding about 25 people at a party.
author: E U.

description:
Filipino food snob alert. 

I am Filipino. I grew up in the Philippines. I've eaten in countless establishments back home since I was a little boy. I live, breathe and LOVE the cuisine.

That said, Irma's is one of the few places in San Francisco that proudly wears that seal of authenticity. This is what most restaurants in the Philippines feel like. And No, I'm not talking about the zillions of new restaurants popping up everywhere in the main city of Metro Manila. I'm referring to the dying breed of family owned mom and pops establishments you will find along roadsides on the way to the provinces and country sides. The ones that stay true to Filipino cuisine.

Yes. Irma's is as close to home as it gets.

If you want the authentic Filipino "carinderia" experience, check Irma's out. The caveat is that authentic Filipino means greasy and MSG-filled food. If you don't mind that, by all means come here with and open mind and an empty stomach. 

If you are not familiar with the process, it's "turo-turo" which is similar to the food court or Panda Express. You grab a tray, tell the guy behind the counter what items you want, and he ladles it onto small bowls along with a mountain of white rice. Most of the dishes are usually saucy so pouring it on the rice is advised. 

The food is good, albeit greasy and salty. But that's the way I like it. If you're not a fan of greasy food, this place might not be for you. This is as close to the flavors of the Philippines as you will get. Go in with this mindset if you are open to new things and you will be fine.

I have met Irma before. She didn't pay much attention to me when I was there. In fact, she was a bit standoffish. She was attending to business with her purveyor about money and he was complaining about how she was paying him too little for his services. Seriously. It doesn't get any more authentic than that.

3.7 stars.
author: Angelo B.

description: I was craving Philippino food so I stopped by for lunch today.I got the special plate and 2 item combo plate with a Snapple.$18.50 total.The food was delish and the service great.Highly recommended
author: Harriet A.

description: Been slowly building out a list of Filipino restaurants in the city and Irma's remains my favorite true to flavor Pinoy food.  Ukoy, bistek, eggplant, and sisig are delicious and of course can't forget the mang Tomas! Also palabok is pretty good and saucy!
author: Josel S.

description: This is my first time not liking Filipino food. I have never really been too picky about it. To me it is simple comfort food that is hard to mess up. I decided I wanted some Filipino food today on my way to work and found this place on Yelp. I got the 2 items combo: dinguan and chicken adobo. Taste was bland, food was slightly cold (I ate it about 5-10 mins after picking it up), and the rice was lumpy/clumpy. The dinguan had way too many pieces of just fat....thick nasty pieces of fat with no meat on it. When I walked in the girl was rolling up raw meat lumpias.....didn't wash her hands and helped me get my food.
author: Jenn T.

description: Old dingy place - legit - not sure I'd return. Chicken skewer was overly sweet and reminiscent of ketchup.
author: Andrew K.

description: Irma's Kitchen is supreme when it comes down to our last minute catering. The best Filipino's food in SF when it comes to their Shanghai lumpias and plantains turnovers.. They will have everything ready within 10 mins and their staffs makes you feel right at home.. Two thumbs up!
author: Teresa C.

description:
I always go to Irma's if I need a party tray of lumpia in a hurry. They take same day orders, I know this as I always seem (although unintentionally) to be placing my large lumpia order last minute.

The lumpia is always ready at your requested time of pick up with a side of sweet n sour sauce. Their lumpia comes crunchy, hot, and very well seasoned.

Only downside is that they accept cash only...so just come prepared!
author: TuUyen L.

description:
They reduce the portion of garlic rice by half. 
Raise the price for the Breakfast to $6. 
My Bangsilog is okay. The Bangus is excellent but the Garlic Rice is a stale.
Oh well. Time to venture off to fine another dive.
author: Toeknee T.

description: Paid 8.50 for a big heap of plain white rice and a bit of meat. Not a great deal but the meat was good.
author: Caleb F.

description: This is the only place i buy filipino food all the time but wtf the pork sinigang mixed with chicken?! Smh its not that good at all and the adobo has hair. For sure im not coming back here ! Even tho how much i liked there dinuguan (chocolate meat) nd the sisig ! But i just have to find another filipino place! Just Be careful wat u guys eat! Dig in to it so you know your not eating hair with ur food.
author: Lara J.

description: Filipino is the Best. All dishes are good you sometimes have a hard time choosing what you like... A lot of space to eat and cool pplz
author: Ryan M.

description: I was craving bbq so I went to Irma's. I had their bbq pork skewer. It was really delicious and satisfied the smoky taste I was craving! The amazing thing is it's only $2, vs $4-5 at street fairs. I also had the adobo, sisig, and lumpia. I asked for individual orders instead of the combos, cause I want to take them home for my parents to try. They were all very good. It would have been even better if there are more vegetable dishes to choose from. Overall, the food was really good and I'll come back! It was interesting listening to the Filipino TV show that was in both Tagalog and English.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
I needed to take my van to my mechanic for a tune-up. So I landed at this "hole in the wall" corner for a quick bite. (standing with pride and honor)...I'm proud to be the conqueror of "hole in the wall" businesses. 

This corner restaurant serves your basic and popular Filipino cuisines. One of only a few food businesses in the area that serve Filipino cuisines for quick bites.

Not knowing what are the popular dish, I ordered the two-items combo. For $7.00, I received two of the available items on the hot-cooker with steamed rice. I don't know the name of the two items, but I got the Flank Steak in a thick vinegar sauce and a grilled chicken with a thick and sweet marinated sauce on a skewer. The meat on both dishes were a bit too tough to eat. Especially the flank steak, which seems to damaged my jaws after numerous bites.

As I was eating my meal, I saw many people were enjoying the Longanisa and eggs over rice. As soon as my van is ready and being a huge supporter for family-owned businesses, I might give this place another chance and try that dish instead. Definitely, skip the combo-lunches.
author: Matt G.

description: I enjoyed this place while in SF. Great selection of food and very inexpensive. The place lacks hospitality. But, the food is decent!
author: Angel E.

description: Love this place! Not the most attractive restaurant (no decor, very plain restaurant) but the food is mostly delicious! I had the tinola, menudo, and tocilog and all were great! The Shanghai was ok. Staff was friendly.
author: Precilla L.

description:
I originally gave Irma's 2 stars, but today Jan 27, 2012 over did that and saved face for Irma's.  

So I came here with my sister because we were craving some real Filipino food.  On the menu today was:
*Tocino (marinated pork BBQ)
*Sinigang Pork (Pork with the Filipino sour tangy soup)
*Chicken Adobo (the traditional vinegar, soy sauce, 7up and chicken)
*Mungo (mungo beans with pork and shrimp)

Today was heaven, and each dish hit the spot.  I couldn't even express how satisfied I was.  At the same time we got to catch up on Filipino news and what was happening in the Philippines while we watched the tv.

Thank you for making me reconsider Irma.  =)  I'm officially a happy camper.
author: Edrian D.

description:
This is your traditional "turo-turo" Filipino joint where you point what you want to and they serve it with rice. 

And yes, it is a dive that looks like it got stuck in the 80s. But who cares? They serve Filipino food the way its cooked back halfway across the globe, with love and HUGE servings! 

Must try: Lumpiang Shanghai (Filipino pork spring rolls), Lechon Kawali (Crispy Pork Belly) and Pansit Palabok (thick rice noodles served with sauce, hard boiled eggs and crushed pork crackling)
author: Gordon O.

description:
Anxiety.  Fear.  Nervousness.

Those were just a few of the emotions running through me as I walked up to the entrance of Irma's.  You see, I have a Filipino boyfriend.  A PICKY Filipino boyfriend.  He lived in the Philippines and always craves a good, authentic Filipino meal.  So when I was giving him a tour of the Mission and he turned to me and asked, "Are there any good Filipino joints up in this place?" I was at a loss.  

I mean, I'm as white as it gets.  When it comes to the Mission, I know Philz, Beretta, Mission Cheese, and any burrito place (see my other reviews regarding my burrito obsession) like the back of my hand... But Filipino?  Can't say I'd gone out of my way to ever find one.  So what does a hopeless white girl do?  Open the Yelp application on her iPhone!

Which, of course, led me to this place!  I was so petrified he was going to hate it... But his scowl turned into a smile when he walked in and saw all of the delicious foods set out "turo turo" style.  (Turo-turo literally translates to "point-point," meaning all of the foods are set out in front of you, and you point at what looks good and hope for the best.)  We ordered quite a few things, including pork lumpia, lechon kawali (fried pork), fried milkfish, and BBQ pork.  Everything cost a total of $12 (yay cheap eats!), was absolutely delicious, and  wasn't overly greasy or garlic-y like other Filipino places he had taken me to before.  In fact, the lumpia was so delicious that if I hadn't just woofed down an entire burrito from El Farolito (once again, I have a burrito problem), I probably could have eaten the entire order of lumpia on my own.

Overall: this place isn't fancy, but the food definitely holds its own, and it gets a seal of approval from both me and my picky Filipino SO!  Go check it out, eat some pork, and enjoy some people watching in this little restaurant on the corner of Van Ness!
author: Christy L.

description: Kind of a scary stinky place! I definetely will not be going back.
author: Jessie R.

description:
Nothing cures homesickness quite like food. 

Sitting on an unassuming street corner of the Mission, Irma's doesn't look like much from the outside. It doesn't look like much on the inside either. The place is well-lit, the tables are clean, and the television is playing at a respectable volume. The staff is warm and friendly and all-smiles. The food is displayed behind a glass panel, turo-turo style. They didn't label the dishes, but if you grew up with this food, it shouldn't be a problem. You'll be able to identify at least half of it.

An order of white rice gets you a mountain of the stuff on a large plate. Huge. It could have easily fed three people. But that's how they do it back home -- the land that put "Extra Rice" on the menu, so I got a sentimental kick out of that. 

The bistek was juicy and tender, and the sauce was great for pouring over your rice. The sisig had the right amount of heat, although I don't think they used the pig cheek and ears, which is what is traditionally used in this dish. I didn't like the tortang talong because it didn't have the ground meat that I was used to. 

It's hard to judge the food at Irma's with the same scale that I use to judge other cuisines, simply because Filipino food always gives me something extra. It gives me comfort and serves up a host of memories that no other cuisine can give me. I was craving a taste of home and Irma's gave me just that.
author: Racquel N.

description:
Holiday luncheons, family get2gether, work potlucks, school potlucks, and many other events in my life, Irma is always my go to place. This review is mainly on their lumpias because that is what I mostly order. The lumpias are out of this world and my family, coworkers, church members, and classmates adore Irma's lumpias. They are the best and even if I have to drive into the city just to pick up a pan of lumpias, I most certainly will. Their lumpias are crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside, incredibly tasty. I don't think there are any veggies in the lumpia which I love (don't judge me). They always accommodate my needs even if I call in last minute.

Another favorite I usually get here is the BBQ Chicken over Garlic Rice. Total delish, but you will be in a food coma after. 

I recommend Irma's to all my friends and family if they are craving good Filipino Food.
author: Nise F.

description:
5 stars for the food but 1 star for service and employee behavior and attitude. I've been here a few times and every time I com here, the cashier, perhaps the owner, and sometimes different employees in the front are always yelling, perhaps even lecturing the employee. And their conversation don't sound pleasing and sometimes I can tell they're arguing. No professionalism at all. I'm sure they have lost a lot of customers or didn't retain first timers due to the yelling and unprofessional attitudes displayed to customers. Also, the cashier/owner was cutting her fingernails behind the counter where the food was laid out. Really? Any common sense here???

Advice: Wait till there's no customer in the restaurant before arguing or yelling at each other. And if your employees are far to where they cannot hear you, walk over and talk to them. No customer wants to hear your non-English conversations, especially when it's yelled out! Also, doesn't every employee have to go through basic food and beverage handling course to get a permit to work at a restaurant? 

If it's not the convenience of the location and the good food, I will totally ditch this place. I will come here more often if they present a more professional atmosphere.
author: Dante M.

description:
Felt like I was actually in the Philippines. Irma picking her nose as she was taking my order. Then her side kick picking her nose as she was watching the Filipino TV programming. Irmas Mom sneezing and blowing her nose around the food. 

Food was tasty and if I get sick I deserve it for not walking out, but we were absolutely starving. So if you don't mind 3rd world hygiene and looking for authentic Filipino food this is the place for you.
author: Richard L.

description: I come here when I am craving Filipino food that I am too busy to make. Their sisig, adobo and bbq are my favorites. I knocked my review to 3 stars because it is a bit pricy for a 1 item plate and one time I ordered talong (eggplant fried with egg) I found eggshell pieces. Not one piece but at least 4 to 6.
author: Janelle O.

description:
They were at the Asian Heritage Street Celebration at Civic Center.  I decided to order their special, which was a few lumpias, pancit, bbq chicken/pork.  No prices listed.  When they gave me my plate, she says $15.  WOW, jacked up prices.  Guy behind me heard that, I turned around and said "yeah, kinda expensive".  He left.

I asked someone else who had ordered at another vendor how much their food costs, $6.  They didn't jack up prices.  Yes, you can charge what you want, but to not list prices...everyone assumed it would be affordable.

Plus, as I was waiting in line, one guy who ordered the "special plate" reached down to grab a drink.  This big guy with dreadlocks who worked with them asked him if he paid.  He said he got the special (and I assume he figured at that price, it MUST include a drink).  The big guy asked the lady if he paid, she said no, it's $1.  Ok, simple misunderstanding.  But I also heard the big guy say something about "trying to steal".  That was uncalled for.

Guess what vendor I'm not ordering from at the upcoming Pistahan festival...

Food was just ok.
author: Peter C.

description: There must be something special about a place that just ooze yumminess as soon as you step in...the first thing that greets you is the smell of Irma's freshly made lumpia. Some so-called expert food reviewers think they know Philippino dishes and flavors better, well they don't. We the Asians, know what is good food and what is better than good because we cook the same dishes at home. That said, Irma 's dishes are just that -- better than good and if you understand Tagalog (or ask) you will soon realize that they, the women, love to joke with each other around the dinner tables ... They may sound like they are arguing or fighting but trust me, they are not. They are talking about how gorgeous your body is! For me, everything that is cooked here is flavorful and fresh, clean and mostly importantly...yummy. Highly recommended.
author: Ambrose A.

description: Party tray was great: pansit, BBQ, fried chicken, lumpia and turon. Ordered it for work and everyone loved it specially the BBQ.
author: Grace A.

description: I highly recommend this place to anybody who loves Filipino food. They give you more than enough. 3 item combo for $8. I go get lunch here for to-go a few days a week from civic center. You get ONE entree at civic center for $12. Here, you get 3 entree (full plate) of whatever you want for $8. Best deal ever lol
author: John I.

description: Because of its lack of appropriateness, I give this slime hole place one star. Terrifyingly nauseating place located in an unappealing neighborhood.
author: Raymond F.

description: Irma's ROCKS. Dat Bistek? Flawless. AWESOME lumpia deal. Sinigang ftw. Come on down to Irma's to satisfy those Filipino cravings. You won't be disappointed.
author: Pam S.

description: Wish I could give this place 100 starts.. BEST Filipino food ever! The BBQ, Chicken Adobo, and Lumpias are excellent. The owner Irma, such a nice lady. I love this place :-) Just DELICIOUSNESS :-)
author: A M.

description:
I have been meaning to come here for a while now, but the first time I walked in, it was sometime between lunch and dinner, around 5pm, so the food wasn't as appetizing then, and there wasn't much of it out. I opted to give it a second chance after helping a friend move just around the corner, and boy was it a great idea.

There were six of us and we ordered three combos and a side of pancit bihon. The adobo was delicious! The chicken tasted like it had been pan fried before putting it into the sauce (which is the right way to do it), instead of just cooked in the sauce like at most places. Solid chicken adobo with good sauce! Bonus points because the woman behind the counter gave us extra sauce, which won Josh K.'s heart over (he's definitely a sauce kind of guy). 

The sisig was also really good. We had to get two orders because so many of us were interested in it, and it was definitely a good decision. It's very crispy and a bit sour, and served with onions and bell peppers (gotta get your greens somehow!). I normally don't like when sisig has too sour of a flavor, but this was perfect. I could eat this stuff all day.

The pancit bihon was decent, but not super amazing. If you need a noodle fix, get it, if not, just eat everything with rice. Their rice is moist and sticky and is perfect for pouring sauce over.

The lumpiang shanghai was good, but there were a few structural integrity problems. It's harder to roll and fry lumpia without making gashes in the side, so I won't take off points for this. The flavor was there though. 

Chicken barbecue! This was another one we had to get two orders of. Perfect sauce, and generally just delicious. The chicken was not mostly burnt (which I commonly see) and it had just the perfect crisp caramelized sauce. Really a winner.

The service was great, and we felt very at ease. This place doesn't get any points for ambiance, but it's delicious and that's what matters. The people running the place were very friendly and hospitable, and I felt at home. 

Definitely bonus points for playing TFC and having Sarsi and Calamansi Juice in a can. I think I have found my go-to Filipino restaurant in San Francisco. :D
author: Angeline P.

description: This is a whole in the wall place but the food is excellent!!! Love the lumpia and adobo. Breakfast , lunch and dinner to go. Yummy!
author: K A.

description: This place is dirty. The food was not even hot. The workers just stare at you funny. My food was not that good. Rice is mushy and soggy. Chicken abodo wasn't good. The lumpia was decent but not even warm. I was craving Filipino food but this place doesn't do Filipino food justice.
author: Jess P.

description: Ripoff alert!!!....Went to adobo festival today and they were here selling food.. ordered 2 bbq's on a stick = $12... $6 a stick.. seriously,  and half of the stick was pork fat amd half cooked pork.. RIPOFF.. I was going to try their resto but forget it..... ripoff alert!
author: Kelly B.

description:
my fave food from irma:

1. bistek *beefsteak" uses quality tender meat
2. lumpia 
3. lechon kawali

Yum! 

Plus Irma will be dontating lumpia to my nonprofit's after school event this week so we are really thankful!
author: Shayenne G.

description: Worth checking out if you like Asain food, has a lot of options.  I prefer the pork/chicken kebabs and shangai lumpia.
author: Clovis M.

description:
I'm not Filipino, but my husband is.  And when we come to San Francisco, we eat lots of Filipino food, because we can't get it back home in St. Louis.  And he is really a gourmet Filipino chef.  So, I'm spoiled when it comes to Pinoy cuisine.

This place is hands down our favorite place for Filipino food in all of San Francisco. Yes,it's not a beautiful place, but the food, oh, the food.  First, there are certain foods in every culture that can tell you about the quality of a place.  For me, it's the lumpia (Shanghai) (I absolutely hate the vegetable one).  And Irma's has THE best lumpia I have ever had (with the notable exception of my husband's lumpia).  Crispy wrapper, moist and exquisite meat filling inside.  You have to have this!  We even got a tray full of this for our wedding reception and there was not one piece leftover.  Very special.

The other day, when we walked in, I immediately smelled the aroma of ukoy.  And they have tremendous ukoy.  They use a lot of annatto, so it's beautifully orange. :-)  But it's crispy and so very delicious.  Ukoy can be very bad (either too soggy or too hard), this is just right.

And every one of their dishes is so very delicious (dinaguan, bistek, adobo, caldereta, gulai, torta, sisig, turon, various silogs) (sorry about the spelling).

We have gone there so many times and everyone was exceptional. You don't go for the ambiance, but you'll come back for the food.
author: Mark P.

description: I go to this place a lot before work or during lunch and I used to love it, , but today, they served my brother rotten torta. They gave him an excuse that it was too hot and spoiled quickly, but even I tasted it and it seemed like it was rotten way before that. I've worked at a filipino restaurant and even though our service wasn't the best and the food was average, we never let spoiled food get served. I hope they get their act together, but as for me, it's a resraurant I've crossed off my list.
author: Vernon E.

description:
I love Irma's.  I love the women that operate this operation. I love Lumpia (50 for $12.00!).

Give 'em a shot!
author: Tom C.

description: With all the Filipinos in the bay, how come we don't have more food spots? Check it out... Don't go walking into places thinking that people need to give you fantastic serves, know the culture and then try to understand it. I come here and it feels like Lola's house...... Look up Lola if you don't know
author: Hilary J.

description: A taste of home. The vibe is very Filipino, complete with Lola making lumpia while watching TFC. My faves: grilled pampano, pinangat tilapia, sisig, BBQ, lots of white rice, lumpia!
author: Peggy P.

description:
YUM! Went here last night and boy do I wish I had been here sooner!

We ordered lumpias (which were fresh fried and delish), 2 bbq chicken skewers, sisig, rice, a chicken empanada and turons. All of it was less than $20 and and on our way out one of the ladies gave us a free eggplant torta! Everything was very good but our favorite was the lumpias. Luckily I think they gave us a few extra otherwise we would've been fighting over them.
author: Nicole O.

description:
Irma's Pampanga saved me from a sulky homesick pre-teen niece from the Philippines. Being my niece's first time in the USA, two-day homesickness was starting to set in, so I took her to Irma's. 

The two women who run the place were so sweet to us and gave my niece a much needed dose of back home. I also got a good lesson in Filipino cuisine traditions and eating habits. I'm a novice to Filipino food, but now I'm a fan. The cafe has a little buffet setup so you get your food fast. We ordered the adobo and barbecue skewers, which were very tasty.

It is near 16th and Mission but not much of that craziness comes into the cafe. Not much.
author: Jen A.

description: Best to come in the mornings when the food is cooked fresh. Stopped by during evening once, and the food served out of the hot tray (cafeteria style) looked a little dry and old. Not sure if you can request thing to be cooked fresh. 4 star rating based on typical Filipino breakfast food -- ohh so good. Don't expect the cleanest of places.
author: Nath C.

description: Reasonable prices and delicious food! I've been craving Filipino food for so long and I was so happy to find this gem in my neighborhood. Irma and her staff are very friendly. I've tried the sinigang, bangusilog, torta, sisig, and bistek. All have not let me down, my husband who's not Filipino is in love with the food :) I'm so happy I found my new place.
author: Trish Z.

description:
I actually typically only come here for take out since I live in the neighborhood and it's a bit of a hole-in-the-wall so I'd rather eat at home with ambient-light and music I like... but never-the-less I love this place!  The food is delicious home-style filipino cooking--and not like the...stuff.. you get from Goldilocks or Manila Bay where they say it's pilipino food and give you the smallest, saddest portions ever.

Whenever I go to Irma's, they cluck at me for being "too small" and then, no kidding, pile about a ton of rice into the to-go container.  Then, because I always do the two-item combo, fill it to almost overflowing so that I'm staggering home under almost four pounds of food (including dessert!).  

I kid you not about this, I weighed my food one day--there were at least 2 pounds in there and I'd already started tucking in.  And I brought home both the Biko (glutinous rice with a coconut/caramalized sugar topping) and the Turon (fried banana eggrolls?), so there was a lot of food.

The dinuguan is really good--melt in your mouth good, and with a healthy amount of chillies falling apart in there.  The pakbit is perfectly seasoned, and the Adobo is super-savory with a little bit of punch to keep the lansa away (the overwhelming feeling you get when you have too much savory food).

Also, big fan of the Biko if they have it.  And the turon... Oh man, the Turon!

Having been rendered speechless by the thought of dessert, I'll leave it at that.
author: Emilynne A.

description:
Solid turo-turo (steam table) Filipino food.  Adobos have a nice vinegar punch... pancit is almost always on offer... and their lumpia are particularly good (get a bunch of frozen ones to-go for your next get-together).

Nothing spectacular here... just good, filling, Flip fare.  Served by nice people in an unpretentious environment.

This is my hangover mitigation destination :-)
author: Mark B.

description:
Review based purely on weekday lunches.

Good / Greasy / Cheap...Yeah, that's about right.

It's a fun spot to get your Filipino food fix.  I will admit my favorite here is the Sisig (sp?) - very yummy.  They give you a lot of food for a little bit of money.  

Be warned: you will most likely suffer from a food coma after finishing your meal.
author: Lisa R.

description:
$5 for a filipino rice plate turo-turo style (pick and choose) for your filipino staples such as:

Adobo with Pork and Chicken
BBQ Chicken
Tortang Talong (Scrambled Egg and Eggplant)
Dinaguan (Pork with Pork Blood)
Pancit (Filipino Style Stir-Fried Glass/Egg Noodles)
Turon (Deep Fried Banana Eggrolls)
Sinagang (Pork Stew with Vegetables, can also be made with Fish or Shrimp)
Nalaga (Beef Stew with Cabbage)
Lumpia (Filipino Egg Rolls)
Filipino Breakfast:  Over Easy Egg, Marinated Meat, and Garlic Fried Rice....yuuum

I used to live on 16th and Van Ness and I NEVER had to cook my own filipino food.  It didn't make sense to since it was cheaper and more time effective to just pick up a rice plate here.  I have to admit though, this place is only for the adventurous ... as it may come across as too much of a whole in the wall.  You get what you pay for folks!  This ain't no sit down, white linen napkin, kinda place.....

Thank's *Irma for cooking me food that reminded me so much of my Mama's!
author: Char C. B.

description:
Oh no... I feel bad giving this place a bad review. But I left the place feeling pretty bad myself. My food was just... not tasty. Maybe because it wasn't hot, kinda luke warm. We ordered some lumpia, pancit and rice. The lumpia was aight. Like a drawn out aiiiiiiiight with my head kinda tilted to the side. The pancit was slightly less aight than the lumpia. It didn't help that some little girl was playing with the tray of pancit (like using a pair of tongs to flick pieces of chicken and vegetables around) right before her mom served it to me.

I dunno, man. Weird, lethargic, sleepy, unexciting kinda vibe. The food matched. I'm sad because it's seriously only 2 seconds from my place.
author: Jennifer N.

description: Cafeteria-style...  Food is not really that good.  They should at least reheat the food before they serve it to their customers.
author: Kit P.

description: I am craving for Kare-Kare and I got one order.  They put the Kare-Kare in a saucer? Who does that??? is is so small and how can you even put all the vegetables in a saucer?  I am a long time customer of this place and they did it to me 3 times.  I am not coming back to this place ever!!!
author: Food D.

description: Decent prices Filipino food that taste good this is the place. may not look like the fanciest place to eat but the food is pretty good.its walk up style with already cooked food so you do not have to wait.
author: Des A.

description: This place is amazing. I love the old ladies who run it and the food is great and so inexpensive. Also, great take out and party plater deals
author: Ryan F.

description: Went with Angeline P. Great place. I have been eating their food regularly at the Pistahan festival in Yerba Buena. We tried sisig, adobo, lumpiang shanghai, pancit bihon, and of course the BBQ. The only dud was the pancit but I see that on other days they have palabok and I would be interested in trying that. Beats the crap out of Adobo Hobo and the sisig nacho truck. I will be back to try more things.
author: Josh K.

description:
Alright maybe im a little spoiled considering i live aorund the corner from this place. But EVERY time i go into Irma's i feel like my aunty is serving me some good home-cooked flippino food. Portions are great and the price is right. cant go wrong with the two-item with rice.  dishes like tinola, kare kare, adobo, and even dinuguan make this place the most authentic Filipino food spot in the mission. 

Turon for dessert is a must.  Lumpia and even palabok or pancit. i can go on and on.
author: Raymon B.

description:
Irmas is home style Filipino food with a family style vibe.

The food is FANTASTIC! The prices are cheap and they serve you a heaping portion for the money.

Everything they cook is really good.!!!!

Its not like places such a Goldilocks or Manila Bay Cusine were the food is just standard and over-priced with minimal portions. Those are chain restaraunts.

When I go to Irmas I order their Tocilong breakfast plate or chicken adoboe.

Their sinigang, bbq sticks, tinola, sisig are sooo tasty!

If youre a newcomer to Filipino food, start with the Breakfast plates, lumpia, bbq sticks and pancit.

Finish of your meal with a desert called Turon.

Everytime they cater food at a street events among other Filipino caterers, they are hands down always the BEST FOOD!

They are always running out of food because people frequently clean them out. SO go early if you want to get the fresh cook! They usually run out just after lunch.

The neighborhood is busy as it is located on 16th and S. Van Ness.

Theres an SRO type bulding next door which has alot of very "intersting characters" coming in and out and lingering around the neighborhood. Dont be alarmed. They LOVE the food too! ANd Irma is really good to the residents. She's somewhat of a saint!

Hipsters havnt really discovered Filipino food they way they have just discovered Thai and Vitnamese food, so enjoy!

Irma's is a DOUBLE THUMBS UP!!!!!!!!!!

Did I mention that Irma's is a DOUBLE THUMBS UP?!

Definitely a hidden gem!!!!!!!!!!!
author: MacKenzie S.

description: I've been exploring the Filipino restaurants here and this place is last on my list to ever go to.   Chicken adobo was luke warm or cold in some spots.  The lumpia was cooked way before we arrived and oil leaked from it like squeezing a wet sponge.  Also, the adobo pusit still had the internal stuff you have to clean out.  Had digestive issues later in the day.
author: Joe N.

description:
i wanted to love this place, i did. one, because i love filipino food and wanted to find some down home cooking in SF; two, because it's very moms and pops/family run and you have to support the small businesses, but the food just wasn't up to par. 

everything tasted like stale reheated left overs, even the lumpia which are tiny. granted, yes you get 12 small rolls for like $3 or whatever which seems cheap, but most were soggy, like they had been sitting out of the fryer and on the line for hours upon hours.

maybe it was an off day, but unless someone will come with me and guarantee me the food will be piping hot and fresh, i won't be back.
author: Melissa N.

description:
I love Filipino foods, and every chance I get I eat them.

Before we embark on our rendezvous, he suggested that we have breakfast first, and like always he ask what I want I quickly replied "filipino" and he said "again?"...since we just had Superstar a couple of days ago.

Since we were running around the city doing our errands, I suggested this place since we have a friend who works here and that its the most accessible before we head south.

I orderd the Breakfast special and Tb ordered the combination. The service was lousy and the food is Meh. Seriously, the adobo sucked oh and Tb got upset because the plate he was using has a crack...seriously.

Will never come back here again.
author: Malou C.

description:
I took my co-workers here (one of them is white) for lunch since its the closes Filipino spot.  I was kinda scared to take them here since it looks dodgy. But to my amazement, it was actually tasty!  They have tons of choices & my sisig freshly came out from the kitchen!  They also take credit cards but w/ a $.50 fee.  

My co-worker had the mungo.  I usually never liked this since its always bland, but I loved it!  Very flavorful and so is their sinigang.
author: Jo B.

description:
It's probably a coincidence that I'm giving this place a 50% recommendation which, I'm pretty sure, is exactly the percentage of Filipino genetic material I'm carrying around. 

High points; the chubby little Pinay girl running around refilling the condiments quizzing me about my dog who I've left sitting out on the corner of 16th and Van Ness (look, my dog is a 15 year old 85 pound black lab, as far as she can probably tell at this point she's flying through the Horsehead nebula). 

Chubby Pinay Girl: Is that your dog? (standing on a chair pointing with both arms out the window) 
M&C: it is 
CPG: What's she looking at? 
M&C: probably you since you're jumping around 
CPG: will she bite me if I go out there? 
M&C: doubtful and her teeth are like pencil erasers at this point 
CPG: can she talk? 
M&C: she only speaks Spanish 
CPG: I know Spanish! 

You get the picture. Anyway, I got my Shanghai style lumpia and cut out of there, scarfing them all down on the 4 block walk home (my dog walks very slow) because 50% of me knows lumpia are like french fries in that their deliciousness drops off precipitously mere minutes if not seconds from exiting the womb-like embrace of the deep fryer. 

Look, the food here is like any steam-table place; if it's fresh it's fine but when it's not fresh it is pelicans-following-you-down-the-beach-not-so-fresh. There's a reason Filipino food hasn't gotten its Andy Warhol 15 minutes of American food celebrity and this place is exhibit A. Flip food is challenging in the best of circumstances and Irma's is not the best of circumstances. 

I'm not blaming Irmas though or CPG because the ghetto funk lies like a stinky blanket over this part of the Mission. How Poc Chuc (catty-corner from Irma's) staves it off is a mystery to me.
author: Milk N.

description:
Ughh I've experienced better. Don't get me wrong, Filipino food is amazing but to pay $7 for 1/4 side orders and 3/4 rice is definitely not cool. I'd give 4 stars if the prices were more appropriate and the food was fresher.

Shout out to Renee, who is a cook over there.
author: Brandon H.

description:
Delicious food!

First off, the food is really good.  Their breakfast (garlic rice, filipino meats, eggs)  YUMMM and CHEAP!

However, the women behind the counter are either really nice or really rude.  The last time I was in there I asked for a dish and was told i couldn't have it because I wouldn't like it.  I get the feeling that they are offended by having a white guy eat there.  The only time they are nice to me is when they ask me if i'm filipino!

The foods good but the occasional rudeness behind the counter has turned me off.  I wont be going back.
author: Aaron P.

description:
Full disclosure - neither my partner or myself are Filipino. However, we both grew up around Filipino people and loved the food.

We had a craving for Filipino food the other day and did some research on Yelp. We really didn't want to drive down to Burlingame and Irma's was in the city. If you're not familiar with the neighborhood it's a colorful place with a lot of soul and violence. Welcome to The Mission, kids.

Great food at dirt-cheap prices.

Very much a family run establishment. We just discovered this place a few months ago and have been regulars ever since. I even suspect that some of the people that give bad reviews are also regulars. Just a hunch.
author: Scott E.

description: My family and I went in for a late lunch after enjoying the sights at Pier 39. Everything looked great and we can't decide what to get. We ended up getting lechon kawali, kare-kare, lumpiang Shanghai, pork and beef sinigang, Filipino-style beefsteak, shrimp okoy, sisig, pork and chicken barbecue, and ginataan for dessert. The food is so delicious and tasty. Irma and her staff were all so friendly and so nice. We're from SoCal, and I think we found our favorite restaurant in the Bay area. You won't be disappointed with this restaurant. Tasty food and very reasonable prices. Thanks Irma, you're the best.
author: Pete E.

description:
I love me some nom nom nom kinda food.

I've always had difficulty walking out of this place without several pounds of food, because I like the turo-turo  (point-point) style of eating.

They show up at other public events, and I always come straight to their booth.

I "discovered" it with a group of friends who don't live in California.  I really like their food, and they have lots of combinations that I enjoy.  They whip out stuff that I rarely EVER get to eat, like okoy and lechon.  There are quite a few things on the menu that I haven't eaten for a few decades and quite happy to do so here.

The one I tend to order from (is it Irma herself??) always gives me incredibly generous portions.  She tens to call me "darrrling" or "swit hart" and only a few people can get away with that...

Every now and then, I think I confuse her with my order...because I order family-sized meals for one person, and if confronted with a choice, I will take all the choices offered.  lol.  I'm sure that's not the only way I've confused her.  lol.

I am a fan of their Turon (fried bananas)...and at an affordable price!  I've always gotten three or  more.  Sadly, they do not travel well.  They are wrapped in egg-roll wrappers, and friend, and carmelized to boot...so they are crunchy and glazed on the outside, and lovely on the inside.

Their lumpia shanghai isn't bad either...but I need to remember to eat everything within the same day, lest they lose crispiness.

Their palabok is not a far cry from one of my aunties...and will definitely do in a pinch (I just wish I had chicarron in a different container to add on, and unfortunately, kalamansi doesn't grow here...)

The barbecued everything is life-changing for many folks and has come to raise the bar for many.  Rarely have I ever been able to bring some home as take-out, because I finish it (illegally) in BART.

I like their condiments.  They even have datu puti suka with chilis and garlic!  Unfortunately, other people have wised up and realized that they have banana ketchup... so it's always gone by the time I get there!!!!!
author: angel a.

description:
dont judge the book by it's cover....if not for the yearly Filipino festival in Yerba Buena I would have never thought I would often find myself in the corner of 16th and South Van Ness,,

Great filipino food. Inexpensive but yummy option for ordering for parties.

I like their sisig, kare-kare, lumpia and okoy!
author: Carrie F.

description: Went here to get turons (sp?) And lumpias for a potluck at work and they took my order in advance! I called them the previous day to pick up and they had everything ready the next morning. Their lumpias are good and at 25¢ a piece you cant complain. Their turons were very sweet and caked with sugar so if youre sensitive to that then tell them to cut back.
author: Tim M.

description: Ordered the lumpia shanghai for my party--so good! After picking up my order, I must have eaten almost 1 dz just driving to the party! I can't wait to order again!
author: Kathy A.

description: The food is pretty good! I love supporting small business, especially my people.
author: Ronnel C.

description: This is the best filipino restaurant ever! Great variety, fresh and absolutely homemade. The owner is very gracious and we had to come back for more after trying other similar restaurants. I would have loved to have the kapangpangan "buro" though..
author: Tina B.

description:
The place might not look too great on the outside, but it's definitely better on the inside. I just wish the place was more convenient, like actually on Mission St. But the part this place is located in doesn't scare me. Seems very chill. The people smile when you walk in.

Along with the other food offered there. It's very worth your money. Think of it: my mom and I ordered BBQ Chicken, Lumpia Turon, 2 bars of World's Finest Chocolate (I think her daughter or something was selling it), some dried fish, all for about $15. 

Of course, I have to say that her lumpia and turon are the best items Irma has to offer. I'm so addicted, I have to go back :) 

If you don't feel like going out to the Mission to get food here, catch her downtown when she has a stand to sell her food during SF's Annual Filipino Fair, Asian American Fair, & I believe, the GLAAD fair.
author: Annie D.

description:
I love Filipino food so I ask my Filipino friends to recommend some of their favorite Filipino restaurants in the Bay Area, they all told me their mothers make the best Filipino food. 

Well, I can't always invite myself to taste their mom's cooking, so I have tried several Filipino restaurants in the Bay Area and I like Irma's the best. 

Irma's is a family owned place...cafeteria style...sometimes you'll find all 3 generations (mom, mom's mom, and mom's daughter) working away behind the counter there. 

I have tried many dishes there and I love every single one of them. Though if you are the health-conscious kind, then this may not be your best dining option...as the food tends to be on the greasy side but very TASTY!

My Number One favorite item there is Lumpia Shanghai! They are sort of like "two-bite-size" tasty meat-filled deep-fried spring rolls Filipino style. I often order a tray of 100 pieces of Lumpia Shanghai from Irma's for different parties. A tray costs only $20. What a bargain and it feeds a village! 

I also had their two types of Pancits served with shrimp and pork with some chopped vegetables, eggs and some lemons for extra flavor (I don't know the exact dish names but one uses thinner noodles, and the other has thicker noodles). They are both delicious. They do have vegetarian pancit for the non-meat eaters.

If you like meat, then try their Chicken Adobo and Pork Adobo with garlic rice...and they aren't stingy on the garlic at all...a plus in my book. And their Curry Chicken is pretty good too.

The only downside of Irma's is that sometimes they close shop earlier than what their sign stated...unannounced, so try NOT to get there after 6:30pm/7pm...even though I think the sign says they close at 8pm.
author: Jen L.

description:
Can't review the storefront, but I CAN review the catering - 
She'll cook anything in large amounts for a reasonable price and then she;ll deliver it piping hot to where ever.  
On recommendation we hired her to provide the food for the Wee One's baptism - she did everything but the Lechon and it was all very very good - Sposo's from Pampanga and all the family and friends (both Caucasian & Filipino) loved it.
We've also used her for Wee-one's birthday & a big family Pre-Wedding picnic - each time the food was great!

Cash Only
author: Robyn C.

description: nothing special really. the sisig was just meeehhhh not very flavorful, ive had better. the lumpia was ok $3 for 12.
author: Craig I.

description: i like the marinated bangus and sisig and an empoly name Agnes is so nice and helpful and freindly
author: Israel A.

description: Located in a janky  spot, this place serve okay food.  Even though the food is placed on a warmer, the food somehow still taste cold.  The price is decent.  I love drenching my food with vinegar.  Im not Filipino, but i enjoy eating the food.  My favorite is the noodle with the eggs.  By the way, if you do decide on using the siracha, please exam it before squirting it onto your food.  The bottle has been placed by the sun so may not be too appetizing.  The price is decent.  I believe for $6 u get rice with 2 items.
author: Mimi S.

description:
The dinaguan is great here and I've seen it done so badly elsewhere.  The barbeque is good too.  The adobo is a little lacking in acidity for my taste.

All in all this is a good go to place for solid Filipino food.
author: John Paul M.

description: Talking about authentic, this is THE place. I think their BBQ pork skewer ($2 each) is the best I have ever tasted anywhere. I have been its customer since 1994, I have never been disappointed once. OK, this is not the best place for eating-in and nothing fancy about the ambiance, but customer services is number one! $6 a full box of rice and 2 entrees, unbeatable.
author: Anna W.

description:
Meh... It might be ok philipino food, but that's kind of like saying 'ok country music'. Unless it's great, it's pretty intolerable.

Nice service though.
author: Andrew L.

description:
I was excited to see this place open since I work blocks away... but subsequent trips to Irma's has been one disappointment after the next.  Besides the lumpia, food is sub-par often cold.  Often times, the food seems to have been there for days... 

I'm driving the extra-miles to go to Daly City.
author: bombo b.

description: Been coming here for a while when I'm in town doing my deliveries. The Place really looks unappealing and dingy but the food here is good. I don't know but probably my Filipino heritage comes out whenever i come here for a hot breakfast of versions of all kind of silogs that you could imagine (Tapsi, Longsi, Toci & Bangsi).My Favorite is the Bangsilog. The manang is quite friendly when you get to know them really. This place kinda gets packed when lunchtime comes around. Craving some Filipino food lately? try this place and you'll be a believer.Breakfast Silogs starts at $5.00
author: Joel A.

description:
I'd never had Philipino? Filipino? Pilipino? food before so my friend La Puta took me here.

It was alright but I don't  think I'd go back of my own volition.  My former coworker J. The Carpool used to tell me that Philipino? Filipino? Pilipino? food was always really overcooked, making it sound very unappetizing.  I think I need a proper introduction to the cuisine from a proper Pinoy.  Maybe then I'll understand.
author: Frankie D.

description: A nice change from the normal Castro brunch spots I hit up on the weekends. It's a family owned restaurant, and for affordable prices the friendly lady will serve you her tasty home cooked meals. I ordered a sweet pork on a stick with sinagong? (tamarind flavored soup). Both were tasty, but I got to admit, not as great as my friend's cooking.
author: Thomas L.

description: When I lived in san francisco my filipino boyfriend and I would go to Irma's all the time. I love their sisig and beefsteak. I am now in NYC and I can find similar beefsteak I can't get the sisig even close to as good as irma's. I want your recipe!!
author: Rebecca B.

description:
Don't let the grubby exterior fool you... because it won't.  Ate there this past Sunday, and the food was uninspired at best and downright nasty at worst.  The chicken adobo was tough and nearly inedible (especially with the shitty plastic forks they give you), while the pork estofado landed in my stomach with a thud and sat there rather uncomfortably for the next several hours.  I guess it might have been ok if I'd been hung over, but I wasn't.  My wife had some sort of inoffensive fried tilapia and a chewy, hateful eggplant pancake thing, the name of which I thankfully don't remember.

The high point of the meal was when someone brought their dog into the place and it wandered from table to table trying bum food off of people.  I'm still curious who got to our table first after we left, the staff or the dog...

I guess the worst part of the experience was the disappointment.  Screw all those "don't judge a book by its cover" reviewers who led me to believe I'd find some sort of wonderful diamond in the rough.  If I were Filipino, I'd honestly be offended by this place.  Suffice it to say I won't be going back.
author: Dave S.

description: We have eaten here many times in the past and revisited Irma's just the other day. We ordered their Sisig, Pancit Palabok, and Lumpia Shanghai.  Their Lumpia was fresh outha fryer, the Palabok was kinda different, and the Sisig coulda used more suka, chili, & clamansi. Maybe it was an off day for them cuz their usually pretty good.
author: gordon g.

description:
Okay folks, lezget real, shall we?  This is NOT the place for the uninitiated Euro/American palate to experiment with the exotic complexities of Filipino/Pilipino/Pinoy/Philippine cuisine (again for the uninitiated, any one of those proper noun adjectives describes the nationality).  I think my fellow Pinoys will agree with me when I suggest that the best place to test your toe in the waters of Filipino food is someone's mama's kitchen, where you're sure to be introduced to the more popular, western-palatable dishes such as lumpia (our version of the ubiquitous Asian fried vegie/meat roll), pancit (stir fried vegies/meat with noodles), and adobo (either chicken or pork marinated in soy sauce, garlic, bay leaves whole black pepper then simmered into an aromatic stew).  You probably experienced these at an office pot luck already.  If that's all you know, stick to it when you go to Irma's.  But beware:  like all turo turo joints (point at this chafing dish, that chafing dish, and order) it's best to get the stuff when it's right out of the kitchen... usually before 11 am.  Otherwise, you will be disappointed by food that's been hanging out for at least a couple of hours:  the lumpia is limp, the pancit is barely warm and is greasy, and the adobo could be dried out.  If my non-Pilipino brethren want to try the other dishes, go with someone who can explain to you EXACTLY what is in them and what makes their flavors unique.  Otherwise, y'all just do a disservice to the cuisine to try something and react with solely "Ew! That was weird...".  Oh also... there is no atmosphere at Irma's (gawd... what I could do in there with an interior design budget)  ...so don't expect any.  Be ready for a cafeteria a couple steps above being a dive.  Irma's is working class and pretends nothing else nor tries to.

Okay... my FilAm peeps.  Like I said, get there early if you want good home-cooked like your mama or lola made.  For real though, when I get a craving for some down and dirty Flip soul food (helps with the hangovers, doncha know), I make it to Irma's early and grab some dinuguan (pig's blood stew with chitterlings), kare-kare (oxtail, eggplant, long beans in a peanut flavored stew), pinacbet (pork with bitter melon, cassava, and long bean), fried bangus (milk fish), sinangag (garlic fried rice), and grab a six-pack of Modelo Especial from the grocery store next door.  

Remember:  Get there early!  I hate our food when it's not fresh or hot.  I even reheat it on the stove (not the micro) when I get home so it tastes like it just came out of the kitchen.  And, I buy their lumpia unfried (frozen) so I can fry it myself and have fresh crispy lumpia just the way I like it.  Only problem is, they charge you the same for the same amount of lumpia frozen or fried.  Seems rather over frugal... but then you know how we be.
author: Ric S.

description: The only thing keeping me from giving that fifth star is the sneaking suspicion my delicious and cheap ($2!) BBQ chicken skewer was soaking in oil. But I can't prove that, so I'm giving at least four in recognition of what was a really good few chunks of chicken doused in awesome BBQ sauce.
author: Jason B.

description: It was about 2 years ago at Fiesta Filipina that I ran across their BBQ booth.  Their BBQ chicken on a stick was a life changing experience. Yes, that good.  It is flavored right, dark meat, and lathered in a sweet syrupy sauce.  Get steamed rice and a sunny side up egg and you're all good.  They do trays for your parties, but it is cash only!  I haven't tried their other stuff though and the place isn't the nicest spot.
author: Jason A.

description: Such bad service it's awesome. The woman behind the cafeteria-style glass counter of premade sloppy food stared at me like my face was bleeding. The BBQ pork was deliciously smoky, the sour melon stew was sour, and the fried Mackerel was super dry but eatable. Decor is exaggeratedly dingy, with cracked linoleum floor, dirty utensils, fluorescent lighting, and flies. I'd totally come back.
author: Geronimo G.

description: Ok, so here's the real me; seedy, sleazy, and just a little dirty...but tasty all the same. Oh, wait, I'm talking about Irma's on the corner of 16th and S. Van Ness, right? Same shit! So, I gotta back up my Aunty in the traditional sense, and whoever the assorted relatives of hers are...they are polite, let me slide cashwise if need be, and they always laugh at my jokes. They probably don't understand me, which might be why...anyway, I get a terrible jonesing for this dish called laing, and when I'm shaking and shivering my way to Irma's to get my laing I'm sure I fit right in with the rest of the fiends in that area... oh, and she doesn't always make it so sometimes I'm just azz out, which is ok since the shanghai lumpia will do in a pinch.
author: Lolo G.

description: Surprisingly, there's not much Filipino comfort food in the city.  I stopped by while I was  getting my car worked on, and I wasn't too happy with the results.  The food was bland and overcooked, and they had buckets (literally big pails) of marinating meat in the dining area.  I could only imagine how appetizing the kitchen looked.  Gave one star because they were nice....but next time I'm going further down Mission Blvd.
author: Mark D.

description: I found this place by accident driving through the Mission district.  Since I found a parking spot across the street, I figured it was meant for me to check this place out.  I walked in and noticed someone sleeping on three chairs.  Hmmmmm....should I turn around and walk out?  Option 1, head home and sit in Bay Bridge traffic or Option 2, have some Filipino food.  I chose Option 2.  Filipino food isn't always that beautiful to look at. This certainly wasn't great to look at.  I had their barbeque chicken on a stick and some beef stew.  The beef stew was not so good.  There were chunks of over cooked liver and carrots that really scared me.  To be fair, their barbeque chicken was pretty darn good.  I just wish their rice was fresh.  It was easily some of the worse rice I'd ever eaten.  Rice eaters know what I'm taken about.  The rice does make the meal and their rice ruined it for me.  They were really friendly and I honestly did want to like this place.  It just wasn't a good experience overall.
author: Antonio B.

description: When no other food will satisfy your craving like a home-cooked Filipino meal.  When you don't want to drive all the way to Daly City.  When you want that tortang talong on the fly with ginisang munggo.  Hard to knock this place when it's really the only place in SF that provides so much for so little.  Don't expect glamour, though.  This is like a true carinderia!
author: Angelo S.

description: I go here all the time for the BBQ chicken which is amazing, as is the lumpia.  Other things are a bit too meaty or adventurous for me.   If you're looking for a quick bite, this is your place.  They have great sauces for all the meals too.  If you're looking to be pampered go somewhere else.  Service is always good too.
author: A K.

description: I love filipino food but the way it was prepared here grossed me out..I went in and ordered the dinuguan with steamed white rice and after trying to eat it at Irma's, I never want to eat that stuff again. There were flies buzzing around me and the food lol..The meat looked like it was just sitting there for days, omg just thinking of it is making me sick..
author: Andy D.

description: very tasty food. cheap. fast. awesome hole in the wall fasheisty.
author: Sharonrose B.

description: I must say that the location sucks and the place is never open but when it is open the place is pretty good. I tried alot of their dishes and i have to say its as good as it gets to a hole in the wall place in the mission area. i would come here again if they're ever open. Hence why they only got 3 stars.
author: Lucky M.

description: myself Being filipino and Pampangan at that I'd have to say the food for the buck is good just for a quick lunch pick up or to feed the filipino food craving. Definitely not a date or romantic atmosphere.  I totally love to support my fellow filipino restaurants but I absolutely cannot support a dingy looking one. c'mon just some fresh paint, decorations/ candles from Big Lots or something and scrubbing would make such a huge difference. i know it's not in the best part of town but I always think that it does'nt take money to have some class. Clean up and you might have more patrons! Luckily I love my Pampangan food so i'm still supporting....
author: Edward B.

description: lets face it, this place is a complete dive, but are we forgetting the review is about the food?  Granted they have a lack of sevice and hygenic issues.  At least we know they make their food from scratch.  i witnessed it! when I ate there, they were using the table next to mine as the designated lumpia factory!!!! all in their bare hand glory.... I gotta admit the "beefsteak" and the "nilaga" is OFF THE HOOK!!!!  its good comfort food and very inexpensive but definitely needs better presentation....
author: BOSS E.
